Award.AwardTitle: 2021 NSF CISE Proposal Development Workshop: Increasing Participation and Competitiveness of Minority-serving Institutions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: The American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE) will conduct a Proposal Development Workshop for teams of researchers working at Minority-serving Institutions (MSIs). The workshop’s goal is to increase the participation of MSIs in the National Science Foundation’s (NSF) Computer Science and Engineering (CISE) core programs. NSF has recruited a three-member steering committee to host a series of workshops in fall 2020, focusing on individual constituent groups: (a) historically black colleges and universities (HBCUs), (b) Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSIs), and (c) Native-serving Institutions. The purpose of these workshops is threefold: (1) to identify research ideas for NSF CISE core programs, (2) to form research teams among researchers from MSIs, and (3) to begin the groundwork on grant proposals. The participant teams that form during these first three workshops will have the opportunity to apply to participate in the 2021 ASEE Proposal Development Workshop.<br/> <br/>The Proposal Development Workshop will be held in the Washington, DC area in late winter/ early spring 2021. ASEE estimates hosting roughly 96 participants. The Proposal Development Workshop will increase the capacity of researchers from MSIs to produce competitive proposals through a program of instruction, practice, and review. The instruction will include interactive training sessions on how to convey intellectual merit and broader impact and how to compose budgets and budget justifications. Practice sessions will include research teams working together on these key proposal areas. Researchers with track records of success in implementing NSF CISE core programs will review the proposals and provide feedback. Following the conclusion of the workshops, participants will provide feedback through an online survey, distributed after the Workshop ends. ASEE will produce a summary of the meeting that includes synopses of the plenary talks, analyses of relevant discussions, and results from the post-event survey. The Workshop is intended to encourage partnerships among MSIs that support the submission of competitive research proposals to computer and information science and engineering programs.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through this award, the American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE) sought to increase the participation of Minority-Serving Institutions (MSIs) in the National Science Foundation?s (NSF) Computer Science and Engineering (CISE) core programs, focusing on three constituent groups: (a) Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs), (b) Hispanic-serving Institutions (HSIs), and (c) Tribal Colleges and Universities (TCUs). To achieve this goal, ASEE hosted a proposal development workshop designed to prepare researchers to craft and submit grant proposals to the new NSF Computer and Information Science and Engineering Minority-Serving Institutions Research Expansion Program (CISE-MSI Program). The workshop enhanced participants? understanding of strategies for developing more effective proposals, with three objectives: (1) to identify research ideas for NSF CISE core programs, (2) to form research teams among researchers from MSIs, and (3) to begin the groundwork on grant proposals.

The 2021 NSF CISE Proposal Development Workshop was planned in collaboration with a three-member steering committee (representing each of the constituent groups). Originally envisioned as three-day in-person event, the workshop was pivoted to a five-part virtual event due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The workshop, held virtually in February through March 2021, brought together 12 research teams comprised of 45 individual participants.

The workshop incorporated a variety of sessions and activities that provided participants with key knowledge on effective proposal development. Plenary sessions led by expert speakers from NSF, academia, and professional societies provided key insights into required proposal components for both the CISE-MSI program solicitation and general CISE programs including: (a) Project Summary; (b) Project Description; (c) Research Plan; (d) NSF Merit Review Criteria; and (e) Budget and Budget Justification. Additional topics addressed included interdisciplinary efforts, collaborative partnerships, MSI student research involvement, and NSF cloud computing resources.

Each session included dedicated time for researchers to work with their teams on their proposals in breakout rooms. The workshop also incorporated a mentorship component and engaged the expertise of six mentors. Each research team was assigned one lead mentor and one supporting mentor. During each workshop session, research teams were divided into sub-groups and placed into breakout rooms with a set of corresponding mentors. In addition to guiding research teams during live workshop sessions, mentors provided written feedback on weekly assignments completed by their assigned teams and held office hours to advise teams directly on individual proposals.

Based on feedback received from the mentors, unutilized travel funds were repurposed to pilot a mini-grant program to support teams as they continued to explore their research ideas in preparation to submit a full proposal to NSF. Nine out of the twelve teams applied for and were awarded a mini-grant. Teams submitted final mini-grant reports in fall 2021.
